reviews.review_msg: As others have mentioned, her TAs are quite difficult graders for a first year course. I was taking third year sociology courses at the same time and receiving much better marks. It was a bit of a deterrent for me for engaging with more GSWS courses, as what is expected overall is just a bit unclear.

Carmen is a great prof. However, the issues lay within the TA's. My TA marked very subjectively, and would deduct marks for things not asked for in the questions. If your work didn't align with their opinions, marks were deducted as well it seems. Rubric was released after assignments were handed back, which made it hard to know what was wanted.

I did 100 with them, criteria was clear, assignments were fair, exams were fair. Now in 101, rubric is incredibly subjective, only revealed rubric after the exam had been graded. Exam material focuses on one specific module. Strict criteria for one 100 word question, yet only revealed this after the fact. Prof is passionate, do 100 as a gpa booster
They're nice and passionate about gender studies. Also makes cool assignments.

The prof is kind, approachable, and responsive to all emails in a timely manner. Only major suggestion is to implement a clear grading rubric for essays. Also, her and the TAs deduct marks for not including a minor point from readings in essays, even if that point was stated in one sentence and was not the main thesis. Very very subjective grading
Is like an english teacher in highschool, if it is not the one answer that they expect then good luck at getting a good grade. No wiggle room for understanding concepts or even your own thoughts.
